header.topics: Planning trip to Nepal; travelling: previous trips and experiences, including trips when much younger; sausages, coffee; the Village Shop; Farm Shop; offering (or not) advice for a new born baby; job as school display co-ordinator; new free school meals system + lunch box content; food, menu, allergies and gluten free diets; husband's work in the home including cooking; war time food/diet; mother-in-law's war time journey from Siberia to Africa; relationships and jobs; sport: Tour of Britain bike race passing through local area, Iron Man and speaker's daughter's training/ achievements in this.
header.activity: Friends discussing Travelling, local rural shops, food and gluten free diets, war time diets and travels, sport (Tour of Britain and Iron Man)
header.conv_type: Discussing, explaining, inquiring, advising, anecdote telling

body.u: so when are you going to Nepal?
in November my last two weeks in November
no but that's the plan and we have got places on a

oh well it's but I don't know who else might want to come she wants to leave it loose and be brave and organise it when we get there and erm I don't and erm looking out the erm looking on websites for flights you can't get a we haven't been able to find a flight for less than nine hundred pounds so
are you gonna fly straight there?
well that was the hope I mean this was
can't you fly to well Delhi and then get a
no go overland it's so nice it's so
mm I could do that I'm happy with that erm
but if you fly in and you fly out it's such a culture shock when you arrive and surely?
well er you're not going trekking are you?
we are going to be walking but we're going to be doing
are you gonna climb Mount Everest?
on a no absolutely not I've looked at it

and it's extremely challenging and doesn't really want to do anything and I said well we won't see anything if you don't walk so erm I want to go on this organised trek which is easy to moderate and is you know whereas you look at some of the others and they might say eighteen miles or eighteen kilometres I should say erm and things like that so I think the one I'm looking at is definitely geared at for people who are erm less fit

which is good but looking on erm looking on the website initially at this holiday it looked as if it was rather expensive but now that we can only find a flight for only find a flight for nine hundred pounds and it doesn't mean seven hundred pounds
I'm sure you can flights to Delhi and Mumbai for four or five hundred pounds can't you?
well if we looked just at those
it would probably be cheaper than looking at Kathmandu
I mean you have you been? because you've been to India
no I've just been to Delhi and Rajasthan but we got internal flights when we were there
mm oh I went as a youngster
oh was this when you were doing your greyhound and before you got to Greece or after?
mm the middle of sort of travelling yeah
cos I haven't done any of it you see and I'm very conscious of that that I may not
things have changed since then cos I went overland and you could go through places like erm Iraq
mm cos you went to Afghanistan
I spent a lot of time in Afghanistan yeah
and then Pakistan and there was fighting then
civil war but it wasn't like perhaps as dangerous as
erm I went on a a bus actually all all the way from London to Kathmandu
but came back on public transport
who did you go with or were you on your own?

the reason I went was because I'd been in a relationship for a very long time with a boy when I was young and erm when we'd split up I felt that I wasn't very independent so I decided that er I should be a bit more independent
so I went to London and bought a ticket a one way ticket to Kathmandu
brilliant didn't realise that was the start of the big one
what did your mother think of that?
well you know parents in those days didn't seem to worry and there were no mobile phones
and you'd er I gave poste restante addresses in a few places I thought I might be going to
yep so I'd send a letter once a fortnight and I'd pick up the odd letter from them once I fortnight
what about international phone calls? when I was in Austria you could do
well in Europe you could but you you couldn't
oh I dunno I never even tried
for how long did you spend doing it then? it must have taken up a very long time
going there I think took about er do you know I can't remember? I've got it somewhere in a diary that I'm close to finding
turning out all my junk erm probably about three months going there
so how did you finance it?
I worked erm and saved money and it was very cheap
I think the whole trip was only I dunno a hundred and twenty pounds or something like that
and I thought I did quite well coming back from Greece on my own
how did you come back on your own?

well erm cos I was there for a year and I decided to go round the islands so I did that and I suppose that gave me some confidence so I thought well I'll be able to travel overland back to England so I got on a bus and went to Corfu and then got the ferry round to Dubrovnik
and I met these four Australians in a camper van on the boat and
but in those d what what year was this?
mm so Tito was still there in Yugoslavia
and these Australians I think they probably weren't getting on very well two doctors and two nurses and they s
on the boat going to Dubrovnik and they said would you like to?
why did you go to Dubrovnik and not Italy?
well cos I wanted to go through Yugoslavia
I was actually heading up to Hamburg where my cousin lived so I joined them and we travelled up through Yugoslavia erm

in their camper van they had a tent as well and then erm where did we get to? I thi we went to southern went to Salzburg we went in the mines there I remember that erm southern Germany I suppose and then I got the train up to Hamburg to stay with my cousin who was
so when did you say goodbye to these people?

I said goodbye to them at er erm Strasbourg but I kept in tou I moved back to London after that and I kept in touch with them I remember going to some parties and one of the guys this really short little chap he used to come round and sit on my lap
in my flat he was really small he was a doctor an Aussie guy
why did he sit on your lap? Weren't there enough chairs?
he was just a funny sort of he just used cos he was I was quite tall and he was n
and I I in recent years since
since my two have been in Australia
I'd quite like to look him up again cos I stayed fairly friendly with him and then I think he must have gone back to Australia or something he was a gynaecologist
ah it has all these connotations this st and I wonder how
did he just do it to tease you and come and sit on your lap or did he have
no well when we were sitting
when we were sitting in the living room with the flatmates and friends and there weren't enough chairs he used to sit
no no he was too short for that I don't think he fancied me
he was like five foot one or two quite small for a guy
obviously bright which was a compensation
so they were both gynaecologists both erm both the blokes so
so this was that was before you met ?
in ninineteen seventy and then I suppose I went on holidays in seventy-six I went on an overland trip to Russia
did you? in seventy-six cos that was in the
well it was no it was on a you know bus with lots of Australians and people so we went
mm as they do on their way home

and we we went through Holland and Scandinavia Finland St Petersburg Moscow poland and then back to England and I think I met soon after that our conversation started by saying oh I've just been to Poland talking about him being Polish
so where did you actually go when you went to Poland that time?
mm I hear that's a really good place to go

really because you could I think they were booked in to go to certain places at certain times and on the roads there'd be check er checkpoints with guards and that checking that you were at a certain place at a certain time and we got to Moscow and you had to have a in tourist guide taking you to the places that you have booked out and the food was not very good either it was summer and it was just cabbages no nice fruit to eat and tea that's about the all there was to drink and then travelling into Poland you could just see the difference that the fields the crops were bigger it just looked so much more prosperous than than Russia
you were quite both quite intrepid weren't you? I don't think I did anything like that
and I I went on another overland trip down to Morocco
thank you that was just in a minivan I mean just
it was just one of these little overland companies so erm went down through Madrid and over to Tangier and down to Fes and back up again that was quite interesting
but it was quite adventurous in those days to go off and
eeven if you went on those trips
to go and live in Greece that I did
particularly from my background my parents had never been abroad
did you learn some of the la the?
I learnt how to swear at people in Greece but I'm not good
but it was a very different
Greece in those days cos you couldn't get things like things like s erm butter or Nescafé or

yeah cos you couldn't get it
I mean there weren't even supermarkets in those days
they were all corner shops it was very

so did a bit he was quite interested in sight seeing so we went up to Delphi and places on my days off

mm so erm we'd all go
oh right and did he take you out?

yeah we went out with his friends for meals and and then it was time for me to leave I came back the main reason I came back was my younger sister was having a heart operation which unfortunately she died through having that but that's why I came back
good job you did then because actually
you got to see her didn't you?

mm I think you were very intrepid both of you my most intrepid thing was going over when I was nineteen on the train going back again to meet the boy that I'd fallen in love with on the erm sixth form trip and I did stay and work there but erm
that was quite intrepid for those times
mm I don't know for me it was I was just a baby really still growing up thinking of sausages back to 's conversation erm and and erm bought back erm five
